sentence1: The reason is said to be as follows: When St. Lawrence came to Lund to preach the Gospel, he wanted to build a church;
sentence2: but did not know how he was to obtain the means to do so.

sentence1: but did not know how he was to obtain the means to do so.
sentence2: While he was cudgelling his brains about it, a giant came to him and offered to build the church on condition that St. Lawrence tell him his name before the church was completed.

sentence1: While he was cudgelling his brains about it, a giant came to him and offered to build the church on condition that St. Lawrence tell him his name before the church was completed.
sentence2: But should St. Lawrence be unable to do so, the giant was to receive either the sun, the moon or St. Lawrence's eyes.

sentence1: But should St. Lawrence be unable to do so, the giant was to receive either the sun, the moon or St. Lawrence's eyes.
sentence2: The saint agreed to his proposal.

sentence1: The saint agreed to his proposal.
sentence2: St. Lawrence thought ruefully about his prospects, for he did not know the giant's name;

sentence1: St. Lawrence thought ruefully about his prospects, for he did not know the giant's name;
sentence2: yet at the same time he did not relish losing his eyes.

sentence1: yet at the same time he did not relish losing his eyes.
sentence2: And it happened that while he was walking without the town, much concerned about the outcome of the affair, he grew weary, and sat down on a hill to rest.

sentence1: And it happened that while he was walking without the town, much concerned about the outcome of the affair, he grew weary, and sat down on a hill to rest.
sentence2: As he sat there he heard a child crying within the hill, and a woman's voice began to sing: "Sleep, sleep, my baby dear, To-morrow your father, Finn, will be here;

sentence1: As he sat there he heard a child crying within the hill, and a woman's voice began to sing: "Sleep, sleep, my baby dear, To-morrow your father, Finn, will be here;
sentence2: Then sun and moon you shall have from the skies To play with, or else St. Lawrence's eyes."

sentence1: Then sun and moon you shall have from the skies To play with, or else St. Lawrence's eyes."
sentence2: When St. Lawrence heard that he was happy;

sentence1: When St. Lawrence heard that he was happy;
sentence2: for now he knew the giant's name.

sentence1: for now he knew the giant's name.
sentence2: There sat the giant on the roof, just about to set the last stone in place, when at that very moment the saint called out: "Finn, Finn, Take care how you put the stone in!"

sentence1: There sat the giant on the roof, just about to set the last stone in place, when at that very moment the saint called out: "Finn, Finn, Take care how you put the stone in!"
sentence2: Then the giant flung the stone from him, full of rage, said that the church should never be finished, and with that he disappeared.

sentence1: Then the giant flung the stone from him, full of rage, said that the church should never be finished, and with that he disappeared.
sentence2: Others say that the giant and his wife rushed down into the crypt in their rage, and each seizing a column were about to tear down the church, when they were turned into stone, and may be seen to this day standing beside the columns they had grasped.
